messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] new release dvd
messages.msgSnippet: Everyone can latch on to one, because the NCJSC reprinted it. http://www.ncjsc.org/NCJSC_Publications_4_04.pdf ... From: arnold frenzel To:
messages.messageBody:
Everyone can latch on to one, because the NCJSC reprinted it.

http://www.ncjsc.org/NCJSC_Publications_4_04.pdf


----- Original Message -----
From: arnold frenzel
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, August 05, 2005 1:49 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] new release dvd


Hi:
The Yamanaka Newsletter is second to none as a useful source of comprehensive and detailed information on the Japanese sword - coming as a newsletter it has certain natural limitations of easy use, ie, it isn't easy to use, but it is virtually without peer.
If you can latch onto one, do!
AF




>>> jdz@... 08/04/05 11:21 AM >>>
I would strongly recommend additionally:



Albert "Kozan" Yamanaka, reformatted by Paul R. Allman, The Nihonto Newsletters, 4 volumes, San Francisco: Northern California Japanese Sword Club, (1994), 2004.





(Yoshikawa Kentaro, translated by Gordon Robson), (Nihon Token Hozon Kai) Novice Course, Northern California Japanese Sword Club, 1990-1992.





The Northern California Club sends a copy of the Novice Course to all new members.

----- Original Message -----
From: Mark Jaillet
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, August 04, 2005 6:50 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] new release dvd


Hey Andres, John & Michael,

Thanks for the references!
It's much appreciated.
Mark


-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Andres Pedraza
Sent: Thursday, August 04, 2005 10:22 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] new release dvd


Mark,

I have both books. Yumoto's is a magnificent pocket reference,
although a bit dated. The Connoisseur's is a much more detailed
reference, covering the same ground as Yumoto's, but with more
examples of every feature a nihonto can have. Curiously enough, every
now and then I see it being offered on eBay, sometimes reaching bid
amounts above 100 dollars. For the life of me, I can't understand
why. Not that the book isn't worth it, but because it's still
available off the shelf at Amazon for less than 50 bucks:

http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect?path=ASIN/4770020716&link_code=as
2&camp=1789&tag=lairofthenecr-20&creative=9325

Now, that being said, the Connoisseur's is probably the best
reference available in English. It pales in comparison to published
in Japan nihonto reference books which can make the Connoisseur's
look like the pocket reference version.

Lastly, another book I found to be a good read, especially as it
covers nihonto manufacture, is The Craft of the Japanese Sword, by
Leon Kapp, also available from Amazon:

http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect?path=ASIN/087011798X&link_code=as
2&camp=1789&tag=lairofthenecr-20&creative=9325

Hope that helps.

Regards,

Andres

>it, you did your job. You have plenty of other venues to peddle this dvd.

>THAT was the point Andres was trying to make.

keeping

>Mark

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] new release dvd
messages.msgSnippet: Hey John, I have come across this series a number of times in my brief research. Where does one find them for sale and for how much? Mark ... From:
messages.messageBody:
Hey John,

I have come across this series a number of times in my
brief research. Where does one find them for sale and for how much?

Mark

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of John Berta
Sent: Thursday, August 04, 2005 10:34 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] new release dvd


Mark and Andres;

The most useful English language reference books in my experience are the
translations of the Nihon To Koza by Harry Watson.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Andres Pedraza
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, August 04, 2005 6:22 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] new release dvd


Mark,

I have both books. Yumoto's is a magnificent pocket reference,
although a bit dated. The Connoisseur's is a much more detailed
reference, covering the same ground as Yumoto's, but with more
examples of every feature a nihonto can have. Curiously enough, every
now and then I see it being offered on eBay, sometimes reaching bid
amounts above 100 dollars. For the life of me, I can't understand
why. Not that the book isn't worth it, but because it's still
available off the shelf at Amazon for less than 50 bucks:

http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect?path=ASIN/4770020716&link_code=as
2&camp=1789&tag=lairofthenecr-20&creative=9325

Now, that being said, the Connoisseur's is probably the best
reference available in English. It pales in comparison to published
in Japan nihonto reference books which can make the Connoisseur's
look like the pocket reference version.

Lastly, another book I found to be a good read, especially as it
covers nihonto manufacture, is The Craft of the Japanese Sword, by
Leon Kapp, also available from Amazon:

http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect?path=ASIN/087011798X&link_code=as
2&camp=1789&tag=lairofthenecr-20&creative=9325

Hope that helps.

Regards,

Andres

an

seen

dvd.

keeping

>Mark

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy) books
messages.msgSnippet: Mark, I second Andres suggestion of the Connoisseur s book, no doubt the best in English.  Here are a couple other cheap books in English worth having:  The
messages.messageBody:
Mark,
I second Andres suggestion of the Connoisseur's book, no doubt the best in
English. Here are a couple other cheap books in English worth having: The
Japanese Sword: A Comprehensive Guide by Kanzan Sato, usually found cheap at
Amazon or other book sellers;
JAPANESE SWORDSMITHS: Commemorative Centenary Edition by W.Hawley can be
found at www.satcho.com or other book sellers, not perfect, but the best
available in English.
Modern Japanese Swordsmiths; 1868-1945, by John Slough available for about
$100 is well worth it, if you are into WWII gendaito, showato blades. Hope
that helps,
Mike

messages.msgSnippet: Mark and Andres; The most useful English language reference books in my experience are the translations of the Nihon To Koza by Harry Watson. John ... From:
messages.messageBody:
Mark and Andres;

The most useful English language reference books in my experience are the translations of the Nihon To Koza by Harry Watson.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Andres Pedraza
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, August 04, 2005 6:22 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] new release dvd


Mark,

I have both books. Yumoto's is a magnificent pocket reference,
although a bit dated. The Connoisseur's is a much more detailed
reference, covering the same ground as Yumoto's, but with more
examples of every feature a nihonto can have. Curiously enough, every
now and then I see it being offered on eBay, sometimes reaching bid
amounts above 100 dollars. For the life of me, I can't understand
why. Not that the book isn't worth it, but because it's still
available off the shelf at Amazon for less than 50 bucks:
http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect?path=ASIN/4770020716&link_code=as2&camp=1789&tag=lairofthenecr-20&creative=9325

Now, that being said, the Connoisseur's is probably the best
reference available in English. It pales in comparison to published
in Japan nihonto reference books which can make the Connoisseur's
look like the pocket reference version.

Lastly, another book I found to be a good read, especially as it
covers nihonto manufacture, is The Craft of the Japanese Sword, by
Leon Kapp, also available from Amazon:
http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect?path=ASIN/087011798X&link_code=as2&camp=1789&tag=lairofthenecr-20&creative=9325

Hope that helps.

Regards,

Andres

messages.msgSnippet: Guess you re missing Andres point here.  This is a message board, NOT an advertising board. You posted your message once, everyone would have seen it, you did
messages.messageBody:
Guess you're missing Andres point here. This is a message board, NOT an
advertising board. You posted your message once, everyone would have seen
it, you did your job. You have plenty of other venues to peddle this dvd.
Unfortunately, THIS place isn't it.
THAT was the point Andres was trying to make.

Just got John Yumoto's "The Samurai Sword" in the mail yesterday! Any
sugestions out there for a must have "second" reference book? Just keeping
things basic at this point. Not specializing in any one specific area yet.
Has anyone read "The Connoisseur's Book of Japoanese Swords"?

Mark
